conclusion: The block is placed on the plate with zero initial velocity.
The plate is moving with a certain velocity.
The block starts to move due to the frictional force between it and the plate.
The graph in Figure B shows the velocity of the block over time, which increases linearly, indicating constant acceleration.
The velocity-time graph is a straight line, indicating constant acceleration.
The slope of the velocity-time graph gives the acceleration a.
Suppose the velocity increases from 0 to v in time t.
The acceleration a is given by a = v/t.
The frictional force f acting on the block is given by f = μ1 mg.
According to Newton's second law, f = ma.
μ1 mg = ma simplifies to μ1 = a/g.
The plate has a mass M = 2m.
The frictional force between the block and the plate affects the plate's motion.
The plate experiences a frictional force due to the block and another frictional force due to the surface.
The force due to the block is μ1 mg.
The plate's acceleration ap can be related to the block's acceleration.
The net force on the plate is μ1 mg - μ2 (M+m)g.
Using M = 2m, the equation becomes μ1 mg - μ2 3mg.
The block and plate move together after some time, implying they have the same acceleration.
Use the relationship between the block's and plate's accelerations to solve for μ1.
Assume the graph shows a specific acceleration a.
Use g = 10 m/s².
Calculate μ1 = a/g.
The coefficient of kinetic friction μ1 is found to be 0.2.
